instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.EDP_BKLT_PWM: What is EDP_BKLT_PWM? EDP_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.LCDBKLT_BOOST: What is LCDBKLT_BOOST? LCDBKLT_BOOST is connected to the SWITCH(SW) pin of the LED driver and is switched to ground quickly after the inductor in the DC to DC boost circuit that boosts PPBUS_G3H to backlight voltage for the screen. .
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight Missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi Guys,

Dealing with <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which has no Backlight. Replaced <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> already but still no backlight. When it turns on, backlight flashes for a second and I can measure <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> going up for a sec but drops after that.

<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> = 2.8V
<SIGNAL>BKL_ISET</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT_FB</SIGNAL> = Jumps to 25V when backlight flashes then drops to 8.5V
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_BOOST</SIGNAL> = 8.5V
Return Resistors measures OK

There is no liquid around SMC
<SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> = 0V

Not sure what other measurements I can post.

Cheers

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight Missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
First check if you have steady image.
Next, try known good LCD assembly.

Read the sticky post about backlight issues; do NOT forget to check XW7720...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight Missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thanks for your reply. Yes went through the tread and based on that was measuring these voltages. 
<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> Voltage Divider has 2.7V
A5 ball seem to be connected properly to the feedback line
Tried with a spare LCD which works with another 00165 still only matrix, no backlight

What is XW7720 ? I saw it on the schematic but don't have anything placed on the board between L7701 and <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>. I tough it is the trace itself or a test point.

Any suggestions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight Missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"What is XW7720 ? "
Search function will bring you out some pictures of it.

Supposing XW7720 is good, remove <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and run a wire from <CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR> to <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR>.
Then do few times PRAM reset.
Remove the wire, put back <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and test the machine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight Missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thanks for the reply. Apparently XW7720 is a trace and not a component. I can measure it A5 all the way to the <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>. So trace should be okay.

Did the wire-jump and it turned on with backlight. Did 3 PRAM resets and removed the jump-wire. Still comes with no backlight.

I wonder if it is an issue with SMC. Perhaps permanent jumpwire is the only solution here, considering if customer is happy with no backlight adjustment?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight Missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
PWM adjust signal comes from PCH, not SMC...

Did you resolder <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR>?
You can join its pads directly, no reasistor really needed.
Very strange to have just 0V there; be sure <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> is not open.
